Award.AwardTitle: Highly Controllable Self-cleaving Tags for Biopharmaceutical Research and Manufacturing Purification Platforms

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1264322
Wood, David W.

This NSF Biotechnology, Biochemical and Biomass Engineering program award will support the development of hyper-controllable self-cleaving inteins. Inteins are self-cleaving protein elements with many applications in medical research and biotechnology. Most central to this work is the use of inteins to generate self-cleaving affinity tags, which enable rapid and simple purification platform methods for arbitrary recombinant target proteins. The development of these inteins will employ rational protein engineering approaches and evolutionary methods with a powerful new genetic screen. In particular, the rational engineering approach will involve the insertion of a designed allosteric metal binding site into the intein structure, which will allow the intein cleaving reaction to be controlled by low levels of metal ion. The evolutionary methods will involve a combination of yeast surface display, rational mutant library design, and flow assisted cell sorting to identify mutant inteins with optimized temperature and pH activity profiles. The highly controllable cleaving inteins generated and optimized via these methods will then be demonstrated in a variety of protein expression systems with a range of conventional affinity purification tags.

The ability to rapidly and reliably purify recombinant proteins is critical for biopharmaceutical development and manufacturing, as well as for pure biological and medical research. One way to approach this problem is through the use of self-cleaving affinity tags. These tags act as 'molecular hooks' to simplify the purification of a given target protein, and then remove themselves once the purification is complete. For a variety of technical reasons, however, existing self-cleaving tag methods have been largely limited to simple proteins expressed in bacterial systems. This work will develop a next-generation self-cleaving intein, which can be applied to the development of very simple and highly reliable protein purification methods for any expression host. In particular, the proposed inteins will allow self-cleaving affinity tag methods to be applied in mammalian and other eukaryotic expression systems, where premature cleaving by existing inteins has made this impractical in the past. Because these hosts are critical for the production of complex human glycoproteins, these inteins are expected to accelerate biopharmaceutical research, and may ultimately decrease the manufacturing costs of these critical drugs. In addition, this work will provide an excellent training opportunity for students interested in biotechnology, biopharmaceuticals and medicine, and will be used as a platform for stimulating interest and expertise in these areas among high school students and undergraduates.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Summary

The importance of highly purified recombinant proteins and enzymes in medicine, industry, and research cannot be overstated. Most important among these products are lifesaving biopharmaceuticals, which are difficult to purify and require lengthy process development efforts before their approval. Thus, an important bottleneck is a lack of simple and reliable platform methods for their purification, which can be applied easily to new protein targets. A possible solution, which is used at small scale in research laboratories throughout the world, is the use of genetically fused affinity tags. This method involves the genetic modification of the target protein to include an additional protein segment (tag), which acts as a molecular hook to pull the target out of complex mixtures using a single, generalized method. Although this method is highly effective at small scale, it is economically impractical for pharmaceutical development because the tags can cause unwanted side effects, and they are extremely expensive to remove at large scale. This limitation has prevented this otherwise effective and efficient method from being applied to the production of countless protein therapeutics, significantly slowing their development and increasing their costs.

 

This project focused on the development of controllable self-cleaving tags, which have the potential to greatly simplify downstream protein purification. In practice, the tag still provides a simple and general method for the purification of the target protein, but once the purification is complete, the tag is induced to self-cleave (Figure 1). This method can thus provide a highly purified and tagless (native) target protein using a uniform single-column method (Figure 2). Although this technology has been in development by a number of academic and industry groups for over two decades, a variety of technical issues have prevented these methods from being implemented in mammalian cell culture. In particular, self-cleavage of the tags is not yet controllable enough that cleaving can be fully suppressed during protein expression, but then activated safely (without destroying the target protein) after the purification is complete. Thus, either the tag cleaves too quickly, and is gone before the purification takes place, or it cleaves too slowly to be practical, or requires problematic reagents. Because mammalian cells are required for making the large majority of human therapeutic proteins, these limitations constitute a major drawback for this otherwise transformative method.

 

Intellectual Merit

In solving the controllability problem, we used two different approaches. The first was based on rational protein engineering, where we introduced a designed zinc-binding site into the tag close to the cleavage junction (Figure 3). This approach substantially increased the sensitivity of the cleavage reaction to zinc, providing good control of cleaving at concentrations that still allow mammalian cell growth. For our second approach we developed a yeast surface-display system to rapidly screen large libraries of randomly mutated cleaving tags. Using Flow Assisted Cell Sorting (FACS) we were able to separate cleaving tags from non-cleaving tags under a wide variety of temperature and pH conditions (Figure 4). Thus, we were able to rapidly identify and isolate mutants in our library that showed better control under conditions that are relevant for mammalian cell culture using FACS. Over the course of the project, we also developed a split-tag system, where one part of the cleavage tag is immobilized on a chromatography resin, while the other part is used to tag the target protein (Figure 5).  Because the tag cannot cleave until it is assembled, this approach provides very strong control of cleavage. Once both of these methods were complete, we worked to identify optimal leader and secretion sequences to express our proteins in mammalian cell culture.

 

Broader Impacts

Overall, this project was highly successful. We were able to construct and validate the yeast display system, and the construction of the zinc-binding domain provided important insights into the effects of specific amino acids on the cleavage reaction. The systems that we have developed have now been demonstrated with protein expressed in mammalian systems, and we have shown that this method can be used to purify fully glycosylated proteins that contain disulfide bonds (Figure 6). Thus, we have provided a new platform method, with the compelling appeal of Protein A for purification, but with the universal applicability of conventional microbial affinity tags for virtually any target. Further, this work provided ample opportunities for undergraduate and high school student research, including several students from underrepresented groups. Students who worked on this project now have positions at companies including Genentech, Genzyme, Regeneron, Proctor & Gamble, Biogen, Merck, and Novartis. Undergraduates who worked on this project have now joined PhD programs at close to a dozen universities, and three of those have gone on to win NSF graduate research fellowships. Overall, we have made significant additions to platform protein purification methods, while delivering several new leaders in downstream process development for the biopharmaceutical industry.
